Surely one of the greatest films ever made-it's just a pity that no one has heard of it (though I can't think why).Gripping stuff, it keeps you on the edge of your seat for the duration. Unlike other low rate suspense films though, this one has great dialogue, great performances (has Al Pacino ever bettered this?) and sharp witted social commentary with added bite.Blood sweat and tears....this phrase has never been more applicable to a film. Fans of poor quality action based movies of the 1990s variety should check this one out; it proves that intelligent yet entertaining films can be made without compromising on either account.

It's rare that a performance such as Al Pacino's Sonny Wortzik in this film is matched. Others like Jack Nicholson's Randall McMurphy in One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest or Heath Ledger's The Joker in The Dark Knight give young actors a chance to prove themselves and show exactly what great talent they possess. Dog Day Afternon is about a young bisexual man Sonny(Al Pacino)and his friend Sal (John Cazale) who try to rob a bank to get the money for Sonny's male lover for his sex-change operation. However, things get out of hand when the police get involved and surround the bank with armed gunmen. The film's most famous sequence shows Sonny walking up and down the pavement unarmed with policeman all around screaming "Attica! Attica!". Attica in question is a prison where, according to the main character, guards killed at least 100 people, innocent and guilty. This movie certainly is very different from other Al Pacino movies in the 70s (With the exception of the two Godfathers) and the direction from Sydney Lumet is very well structured.

This is one of the classics.  Worth watching a few times -- it's still as powerful today as it was when it came out.  I remember this film as a child -- seeing it, could it be, on t.v.?  I didn't understand everything then, but it inspired me.  Now, the idea of making a film with this story is unthinkable, because films are so large, and the risk too great.  DOG DAY AFTERNOON is an example of a time when filmmaking that took risks, expressed a voice, and was unafraid to be political also had the ability to get wide awareness by audiences.  Terrific performances.   Superb writing.  Subtle, gutsy, and refined directing.  I admire most anyone involved in this film. A Great American Film.
How can anybody give this movie less than a 10? It's a perfect movie in every way. The acting alone is legendary, the performance by Pacino probably the greatest single job of acting ever done.

Review title: very real on a big screen
Review_body: Three years back I had the opportunity to see Dog Day Afternoon on the big screen. Perfect illusion of being real, events really happening where you saw only the screen during the commercials. The excitement stays on all the way thanks to a very clean perspective. The spectator is placed as a bank robber inside the bank. Almost all outside shots are in a style you would see the events during a live TV coverage. The bank robbers actually do watch TV while in the bank so the perspective stays intact.Practically all characters in the story are way beyond people I would ever know so I cannot comment on the actor's performance here. However the bank robbers do change as the events approach one climax after another in a way that is believable.

This was a great movie because the mane character was robbing a bank but it wasn't for a bad reason it was an operation for his wife. Al Pacino was amazing Im this one of his best performance and one of my favourite.

Review title: A laugh riot with a poignant ending
Review_body: Had friends staying with me over New Years, and we watched this film which was new to all. We laughed so hard that windows and glasses fogged up, and we had to stop the video several times to have any chance of following the dialogue. This despite the fact that 'Dog Day Afternoon' is based on a true story, and that the ending is quite sad (but very 'right' for the film).The film might work best if watched with a (good) crowd, and for us it was excellent. 5 out of 5 people, all reasonably discerning moviegoers with normally widely varying tastes, loved it. A clear and unprecedented 10 on the IMDb scale from all of us.

DOGDAY AFTERNOONEvery movie has a setting. Every movie has a plot. Yet it is only when the two are so heavily dependant on one another, and so intertwined to become the sole backbone of the film, that a movie like Dogday Afternoon comes around. And there are few films that remain faithful to the facts of a real-life true tale. These are things to consider as we witness the historical re-enactment of one of the most famous bank robberies of our time.From start to finish you will primarily see only two locations in this film's setting: The bank, where history was created, and within the vehicle, where it suddenly ended. Sidney Lumet's emphasis on having nearly an entire film take place behind closed doors illustrates the intensity and heightened tension of every character's situation. The only other scenes that were filmed away from the bank were roughly on par, perhaps, with the number of audaciously performed acts of him emerging from within. Yet most of the pressure arises from the inside. Then people start becoming very hot, very hungry, and very very stir crazy. And whenever Sonny steps outside, he releases all that energy out onto the awaiting crowds, furthermore fueling his supportive fans.As much as the inhabitants of the bank are gradually exhausting, a phenomenal occurrence takes place; Sonny has won the favor of his own hostages. This fact was one of the most intriguing processes in film history. As the film proceeds from the intro, the majority of the captives slowly unveil their eyes to realize the true nature of Sonny's intentions and motives. They realize that this man is no killer, this man is no lunatic, and for all essential practicality, Sonny (last name) is no criminal.This feature is truly a milestone in blockbuster history, and any viewer can attest to the captivating journey through history's window of intrigue. This film should have the impact of leaving someone nothing less than speechless, and rendering at least one major conclusion to its purposeful essence: This film is powerfully important.Many inhabitants of this great planet will make a weekly trip to deposit their hard-earned wages, and many go daily. But next time they step outside their doors, perhaps they should take a closer look at what the mornings atmosphere has to offer. Maybe even take a long drink of the fresh air's pureness. Absorb the finer details of life's greatness and hopefully realize, today just might be a Dog Day Afternoon.

A homosexual man wants money for his lover to have a sex change operation - the film shows his attempt to rob a bank and the hostage situation that follows.If I had known in advance what the film is about I would certainly never have watched it, which would have been a great pity. It is a most engrossing film with an absolutely great, very high-energy performance from Al Pacino.
It's been a long time since I saw the film but I cant imagine it getting dated. The power of the acting would keep it fresh.

Dog Day Afternoon is another brilliant collaboration between director Sidney Lumet, and actor Al Pacino. The story's pretty simple, two guys rob a bank, something goes wrong and they're caught in a shitty situation with a ton of cops. The film's strong point is in it's characters.Al Pacino plays Sonny, a young guy who along with his partner, Sal execute a bank heist. The cops get wise to what's going on and a job that should have taken ten minutes goes from the afternoon and long into the night.Based on a true story, this film makes you root for the bank robbers. Without glorifying what they're doing, Lumet is able to show a sympathetic side to the criminals.One of Pacino's best performances, this film is a must see for any crime film fans.

Review title: Al Pacino cementing his role as the greatest icon so early in his career
Review_body: One word! WOW! Dog Day Afternoon is an amazing classic enduring the test of time. I find the movie one of the greatest tragic-comedies interspersed with pathos leading towards the sublime tragic heights. And one of the greatest factors in gaining that status is the unparalleled acting by Al Pacino. I really wish that this movie is watched by everyone today to appreciate what brilliant cinema is like and to watch in awe & understand as to why Al Pacino received 5 successive Oscar nominations in only his first 6 years into movies- a feat that leaves me awe-struck even to this day- The man is BRILLIANT in DDA to say the least. The way Pacino conveys his innermost fears, intensity, love, vulnerability, strength, optimism and innocence (all at one and the same time) with his eyes and his body language is a treat to watch. He leaves you wonder-struck and enchanted. I truly believe it was highly unfair on the part of the Academy not to have awarded him an Oscar for this. He genuinely deserved an Oscar for such a riveting performance. I highly recommend the movie to everyone. It should be a 'must have' DVD in one's movie collection to appreciate and treasure Al Pacino's excellence in Dramatic Art.

Review title: A beautifully handled journey into futility
Review_body: My first viewing of this film was many years ago, but I was  probably mid-teens and too young to really enjoy it.  Sometime later I saw the book for sale on a 2nd hand stall and bought it.  Motivated by a truely fantastic book, I have seen the film about 4 or 5 times since, the latest being last evening.The performances given by all the main characters are outstanding.  Some of the camera work and editing are superb, Lumet captures the essence of the carnival this event must have been wonderfully well.I recommend this film to all as a fantastic reminder of the importance of honesty with those you love, but most importantly with oneself - know who you are and what you want, no endeavour is futile...unless, of course, you want it to be.

Review title: Supposed classic is actually rather dull
Review_body: I was not alive in the seventies to see this movie the first time around. In 2002 when I did finally first watch part of it on video, I felt myself becoming more and more depressed about the world.  The setting of the film, the pacing, the seemingly directionless progression of events, all seemed to leave a bitter, stale taste in my mouth.  It was, in a way, fascinating to see Al Pacino at a much younger age than the movies I have always seen him in.  And the dynamic of the crowd jeering during his scenes outside brought some energy to the film that began to interest me, but I turned it off, somewhere near three quarters of the way through the film, because frankly, it didn't entertain me enough.  I still believe in Al Pacino as a great actor, but Dog Day Afternoon left me feeling as though I had wasted my time. My advice would be that you don't waste yours on it, despite rave reviews of so many self-important critics of the classics of movies.

This film is simply superb. It is so refreshing to watch a movie that is so entertaining and captivating without being filled with the usual high-speed action, flashing lights and violence that you would normally expect in a movie of this genre.The brilliance of this movie lies in the performances of the characters- it undoubtedly has one of the best casts in any movie ever made. Every word spoken, every action, every look by every character is immaculate in its intention. The film also gives us what I believe is one of Pacino's best performances, from start to finish he is utterly enthralling, particularly in the famous 'ATTICA!' scene, the scene where he is speaking on the phone to Leon and then his wife and of course the scene where he is creating his will.To conclude, I loved this film.

Review title: A refreshing new take on a bank robbery
Review_body: First off, I'd like to say that this is one of my favorite movies of all time. Probably my absolute number one. The reason I liked it so much was how the bank robbery was portrayed. Yeah, yeah, Sonny *was* robbing a bank. He was a criminal, obviously. But the way the movie twists and turns, it makes you kind of forget about that, and sympathize with him. It takes you through the rocky road of his life and really kind of lets you see with his eyes. Al Pacino, who has never let me down in delievering an unforgettable performance, is a genius, and really brings the character to life. The light tone of the film in general, a mixture of every detail in the whole movie really, makes it something you would not want to miss.

This high-tension thriller captures the true events of one summer afternoon when accomplices Sonny (Pacino) and Sal (Calzale) walk into a Brooklyn bank, and rob it. Of course not all goes to plan. An hour later they're still inside and the bank is surrounded. Cops, media, crowds of fans and the FBI are each hanging to Sonny's every word  and why? Because he has 9 hostages as pawns, a bank as his board and all the time in the world to think up a strategy. Inside the bank however is a different story. You can't help but sympathise with Sonny (due to Pacino's terrific performance) as the first-time bank robber who's unprepared, out of his depth, and just trying to think up a way out. Even the audience begin to feel the effects of Stockholm Syndrome as Pacino's character gains our affections. The 'villain who's a nice guy at heart' could have been disastrously cliché but Pacino's portrayal is nothing short of brilliance. Even Sal with his morbid disposition is magnetising as his childlike innocence shines through. Calzale was wonderfully cast as this awkward accomplice, wordlessly following Sonny. A huge success combining the skills of Lumet with the talent of Pacino for the second time in Pacino's best role yet. A true story that's compelling and tragic but most of all tangible  and that's what makes it so powerful.

Review title: Tell em to put their guns down . . .
Review_body: This is a very, very decent movie.The reason being is Al Pacino's unbelievable performance. He held this movie together. He knew his character and you could tell he was having fun playing him. He took you on this ride as though you were there as well. You even start thinking about what you would do if you were him, in that bank, under that much pressure.The late John Cazale is very good, as well. He doesn't say much, but you can understand his character by the very expressions on his face. It is fun to watch, like the entire movie.The overall plot and storyline is thin and I feel that they notched up the the homosexual sub-plot for more effect on the whole story.One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest deserved the Oscar for Best Picture, but Pacino deserved his Oscar as Sonny.

I've seen this movie and for me it's Al Pacino at his best! The movie has a very simple premise, two guys rob a bank, but everything that can go wrong does. In the beginning the women who work in the bank are afraid, but once the situation escalates into a sideshow, some the women become comfortable with the situation. Basically, the entire movie is in the bank and all types of comedy and drama surrounds it. This is Al Pacino early in his career and for anyone who hasn't seen the movie, I definitely recommend it. Just keep in mind between all the madness you see in the film that this is a true story, and very entertaining!

Review title: Very Realistic. Lumet is a genius. Pacino is a legend
Review_body: What I liked most about this movie is that its very TRUE and REALISTIC . And I mean in all the ways, the hostages' feelings and reactions, the relationship between the hostages and the rubbers, the rubbers reactions and how do they handle the situations. It was all very realistic. And that means the great directing from Sidney Lumet which I think should have won the Oscar instead of Milos Foreman for One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest. But above all the great and unbelievable performance from the legend Al Pacino which I also thing should have won the Oscar instead of Jack Nicholson for One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest, although Nicholson was great !! We also shouldn't forget John Cazale and his wonderful performance. At the end, Dog Day Afternoon remains as one of the best classics ever made and unforgettable film.

I believe this movie is what you call a "sleeper". It is not a hugely popular movie (i.e. it's not played verbatim on cable) but it is a moving, if not humorous, film.The main reason why I enjoyed it was the relatively small cast of characters. There was Pacino, brilliant as always, his co-horts, the hostages and several members of the police squad. Granted, the streets become filled with onlookers, but they are extras-we do not know any of them personally. A small cast makes for less confusion and more attention is paid to the core story.John Cazale, who was previously scene with Pacino in "The Godfather" and later with Robert DeNiro in "The Deer Hunter" is wonderful in his role of the troubled and nervous bank robber, Sal. Poor, poor Sal. Mr. Cazale was a gifted actor and it is a shame that this one was one of his last movies. But it's probably also one of his finest.Al Pacino, a terribly gifted actor, turns in another stellar performance, riding high off the success of the "Godfather" movies from the previous 4 years. He is constantly under pressure, nervous, confused, but very believeable, sometimes humorous. The scene in which he screams "Attica! Attica!" at the police is the most moving moment in the film and also one of the most powerful scenes in all of cinema history.Do yourself a favor and sit down with this movie. The story line will capture you from the moment you start watching. No time is wasted on preliminary scenes or planning. You start watching and Boom!, there you are, in the middle of it all. The film will take you on a ride of emotions and feelings and will not let you off until the credits start to role. Then, you will be utterly stunned at what you have seen.

'Dog Day Afternoon' is definitely one of the finest films of the 1970s. It perfectly captures the pessimistic view of America at the time, and succeeds in creating the ultimate anti-hero whom people across America turned to. The film has a very simple storyline. Sonny (Al Pacino) and Sal (John Cazale) attempt to rob a bank, but only manage to get $1100. To make matters worse, the police arrive and the duo are trapped in the bank with 12 hostages. Sidney Lumet had already proved his ability to direct long conversational scenes with his masterpiece '12 Angry Men', but Dog Day Afternoon', as mentioned before, does so in a much more sympathetic manner. The audience feels real sympathy for Sonny, despite his criminal intentions. The character struggles through life as so many Americans did at the time. Sonny is kind hearted, and his inexperience and struggles only earn him more sympathy. Al Pacino portrays Sonny in a very realistic manner, based upon the real life Sonny whose attempted robbery inspired the film. The sympathy and support for Sonny is intensified further when crowds in the film cheer him on, and the issue of homosexuality was raised, being a controversial topic. These make 'Dog Day Afternoon' an almost unbearably realistic film, and this only enhances the quality of its direction. The mixed pace of the film, sometimes fast and sometimes slow only intensifies the confusion experienced by Sonny, and again intensifies the sympathy toward him. The film is intense, and this is a result of the pace as the audience feels the anger and frustration that the characters do, unaware of what will happen. This is a very successful feature of the film. However, this does remove the ability to revisit the film regularly as the impact is not the same the second time around. Nevertheless, I consider 'Dog Day Afternoon' to be one of Pacino's best films, and also John Cazale's second best performance. The chemistry between Pacino and Cazale (real life friends) is clearly visible on screen and adds massively to the film's emotion, especially at the end. Had the film not been up against 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest' for the Best Picture Oscar in 1976, I am sure that 'Dog Day Afternoon' would have won. This is a must see film guys, and definitely as fiercely relevant now as it was in 1975 in my opinion!

I absolutely loved this movie, if only for Al Pacino's performance. He was beautiful to watch in this role as an amateur bank robber in a crime-gone-wrong. I adore Pacino's acting and this film definitely in on par with his other work. Viewers may also notice Chris Sarandon's great performance as Leon. The casting was excellent and the movie, though tragic, is just fascinating to watch. Rent it, if you haven't seen it.

Che Wiechart MLK: Dog Day AfternoonDuring "Dog Day Afternoon" the viewer's watch as a poorly organized bank robbery takes place by three average male figures. The robbers dwindle down to the two figures that become the main characters of the film, Sunny and Sal. The rest of the film becomes about how they deal with the stages of the robbery gone wrong and the slow decline of their beliefs of a possible escape.Many elements in this film represented meaningful messages that a close eye could make complete awareness of. The beginning of the film the camera shows different views of the city in which the story takes place. It pans from a well-kept city locations to the not so great looking areas. This shows that every good thing has a bad side, showing that good and bad happen in all situations. In context of "Dog Day Afternoon" it resembles Sunny's personality. It the beginning he attempts at the bad robber, yet ultimately fails at such role. He then becomes compassionate, hindering to the needs of his hostages in ways such as getting them pizza and sodas, to having aspirin delivered (Analysis). Another aspect of the film became the use of guns. These showed who had power and control of the situation. However, Sunny uses the use of guns as an attack against the police, thus guns become a intimidation to the situation (Analysis). The white handkerchief used by Sunny to represent a sign of good intentions. Whenever he flashed the handkerchief he had the intention of doing well and bringing no harm to anyone. It also came as a sign of defeat, he left the safety of the bank and his gun in order to listen to what the head police officer had to explain (Analysis). The broken air conditioner represents how heated the situation becomes. When the air conditioner broke Sunny and Sal became desperate for a solution of escape. The heat represents the scrutiny in which Sunny and Sal find themselves under (Analysis).When evaluating a message the judging of an element to some other standard occurs. In terms of "Dog Day Afternoon" the question that the audience asked became, do Sunny and Sal fit the common identity of a bank robber? In terms of today's society a "bank robber" fits under the terms of menacing violent people who will stop at nothing in order to achieve what he or she desires. However, Sunny and Sal appear complete opposite, actually becoming concerned for their hostages. They even sent someone out for pizza, soda, and aspirin because the hostages had not had dinner yet. The complete opposite of what people think of when bank robbers come to mind (Evaluation). In judging the message element to some standard grouping becomes apparent. In "Dog Day Afternoon" numerous grouping situations happen. The love relationship between Sunny and Leon compared to that of Sunny and Angie posed as a grouping instant. It showed the different love that Sunny had for other people. Saul and his quietness also posed as a grouping method in this film. Saul became a man of little words through the entire operation as Sunny took over the role of communicator (Grouping). When one infers a pattern across a small set of elements, then generalizing the pattern to all elements take place. In this situation, how did usual media choices influent the meanings found in "Dog Day Afternoon"? Bank robbers generally interest society because many movie producers make movies about such situations sparking said interest. Sunny and Sal did not describe the typical robber. They had soft easily broken demeanors, whereas other robbers do not. The predispositions people have about bank robbers led the audience the seriousness of the robbery did not impose such a threat (Induction).When using general principles to explain particulars in "Dog Day Afternoon" one deems bank robbers as extremely threatening peoples. In other words these general principles discerned from past experiences lead the audience to believe that the robbers in this film held them same demeanor of extremely threatening. Review title: Analysis after first time viewing of Dog Day Afternoon
Review_body: Films starring Al Pacino tend to involve heavy criminal activity, and the 1975 film, Dog Day Afternoon, is no exception. Moving from the surface, upon reflection, the Lumet-directed film is less about a bank robbery gone awry, and rather focused on anti-establishmentism and a rebellion against cultural expectations. Sonny (Pacino) breaks both tangible laws and social laws by leading a bank robbery, holding hostages, participating in homosexuality, and practicing polygamy. The opening scene of the film is outside a bank where Sonny sits in the front seat of a vehicle and Sal (John Cazale) sits in the back seat. I perceived their seating order as indicating the roles of Sonny as a "leader" and Sal as a "follower". This aspect is heavily reinforced throughout the picture as Sal will only perform an action when Sonny instructs him to do so. Sonny himself conveys this to police negotiators by telling them, "I bark, Sal bites." Aside from these moments, Sal is intemperately in the background, influencing the viewer to perceive him as unimportant. In the final minutes of the film, Agent Murphy creates a diversion and swiftly shoots Sal in the head, then proceeds to arrest Sonny. Even in death, Sal is merely a casualty. Bank robbery films always have a revelation scene where the robbery is announced, but Dog Day Afternoon delivers this scene unexpectedly. When Sonny and Sal enter the bank, Sonny carries the gun packaged in a white box with a lavender lace bow, resembling a delicate gift. Following this, Sonny attempts to reveal his gun, but he haphazardly fumbles and the box falls to the floor. This idiosyncrasy demonstrates Sonny and Sal's general unpreparedness. Though the act of robbing a bank is viewed by society as destructive and masculine, the core of Sonny is actually quite the sensitive man. This is demonstrated many times throughout the movie as Sonny intentionally waits for the woman and her child to leave the bank before he announces the robbery, and again when he spray paints the security cameras rather than smashing them. Perhaps the biggest demonstrations of his true nature are when he announces, "I'm a Catholic, okay? I don't wanna hurt anybody.", and his insistence of paying for the pizza he orders for the hostages. The scene in which Sonny gains support from protesters by continuously chanting "Attica!", reveals the true focus of the film as anti-establishmentarianism. "Attica!" is referring to the Attica prison riot of 1971 wherein prison guards showered crowds with gunfire to control a prisoner uprising, thus killing the guilty and the innocent simultaneously. The prisoners initiated the rebellion as a demand for better living conditions. This chant indicates that Sonny and the crowd are against the oppressive nature of the cops, which in Dog Day Afternoon, represent societal norms.Though most of the elements that profoundly impacted me were based on dialogue and action, there were also technical aspects that influenced my viewing experience. Towards the end of the movie when Sonny is outside negotiating with Agent Sheldon, there is a defined shadow from a telephone line that stays between the two characters as they speak. As the conversation continues, Agent Sheldon lurches closer and closer to Sonny, ultimately standing right behind the telephone line shadow, but never crossing it. The telephone line shadow demonstrates the clear gap between Sonny's values and "normal" society values. The element of shadowing is also used as an omen to foreshadow Sal's death. The billowing shadows casted over Sal's body during the limousine ride to the airplane indicate a heavy, dark experience in his near future. The other significant technical element I noticed was spacing. In many scenes of the film, Sonny is in the middle of a crowd of people, making him the center of attention as well as facing everybody else alone. The viewing of Dog Day Afternoon also strengthened my ability to recognize broad film patterns. After watching the movie, I came to the realization that many films produced in the 1970s have a massive emphasis on irresolution, the concept of endings initiating more questions rather than tying up loose ends. Sal's death and Sonny's arrest in the last two minutes of Dog Day Afternoon demonstrate that the 1975 film does not fray from the aspect of irresolution. Other notable films that I noticed this trait in include: The Godfather (1972), One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975), and A Clockwork Orange (1971).

When you love somebody, you do everything you can to make them happy; you may end relationships with others who feel strongly about or go to the extreme of robbing a bank, just to see them smile. It is unfortunate that sometimes, these things that we assume might make a loved one happy are not really what they are looking for. Sonny clearly thought that Leon would see his efforts and perhaps take their relationship to another level. Poor Sonny-his master plan ends up in a series of tragic mistakes. The producers did a great job with the over view of New York in the beginning which orients the viewer with the Brooklyn community as it was in 1972.We also see a dog eating out of garbage bags during what seems to be an afternoon. The dog represents what Sonny's life has now come to. Sonny is unemployed and resorts to bank robbery. The movie also has a lot of firsts; for example, Sonny is a first time robber at First Brooklyn Savings Bank. This movie was also one of the first to deal with trans-gender issues. Whereas I knew that issues involving trans-gender and homosexuality are controversial, I didn't know that these same problems existed even in the 70's. The 1970s was a time when women's rights were starting to be redefined and when they started to experience the kind of freedom they had never enjoyed before. This movie shows the freedoms through the use of female bank tellers. The women also take on their typical roles as care takers by trying to stick together and take care of each other. Likewise the men assume their typical roles as heads/ leaders. This is shown not only by through the bank manager and the office guard, but also through the phone call that was received by one of the bank tellers from her husband, wondering when she would be back home. There are several signs in the bank saying things like, "All-purpose loans" and "Change your vacation dreams". These signs symbolize the dreams that Sonny and Sal have for a better life. But the irony is that these dreams and hopes are being advertised in a neighborhood that is not at its best. The crowd is able to connect with Sonny because they all experience the same challenges in their lives. Even if Sonny is the one holding the gun right now, it could have been any of them in this situation. Sonny excites the crowd when he starts to yell, "Attica! Attica! " Attica was a prison in New York where a riot was staged by prisoners who were furious about the poor conditions under which they were living. During this riot the police retaliated with extreme violence. Sonny therefore refers to Attica to draw the crowd to his side. Like many films in the 1970s, Dog Day Afternoon depicts the challenges that ordinary citizens had with those in authority. The journalists covering the story of the bank robbery seem to avoid the real issues of the problems people in Brooklyn are facing and the truth is often "sugar coated" for the public. This is seen when Sonny is being interviewed on television and when he starts to challenge the reporter, he is cut from the show. The crowd outside is also seen to mimic the officers as if to show that they are mere puppets to the authorities. There is good use of special camera effects when Sonny shoots the back window of the bank- the cameras shift from one scene to another, showing the ongoing chaos and panic and creating a mood filled with tension and suspense, which makes the event seem more vivid, especially for those that actually know what happened on that fateful day.

Dog Day Afternoon is a film based on an article from Life magazine about a robbery that occurred in the seventies in Brooklyn. A man named Sonny and his accomplice Sal attempt to rob a bank to come up with money for Sonny's gay lover's sex-change operation. Sidney Lumet does a great job directing this film, essentially recreating the actual robbery that occurred in New York. Sonny's character seems very masculine throughout the opening sequence, he immediately takes charge. The cliché bank robber always tries to scare the bank teller into rushing to the vault, much like what Sonny does. The irony in the film is that Sonny is revealed to be a homosexual so his masculinity is feminist. Sonny's gay lover Leon goes on a rant to the police officers that Sonny is a crazy person when he is around him, but he is a good father to his two children that he has along with a wife. This provides a parallel to Sonny's character, he has two personalities, and this could be said about all people who are bi-sexual or sexually confused. Lumet uses the bank as Sonny's place of negotiation, inside the bank is where Sonny feels protected from the police. Although Sonny steps outside the bank to make some negotiations, his accomplice Sal stays inside. Sal represents the paranoid friend in cliques that is constantly over-thinking their decisions. Regardless of their personalities, both Sonny and Sal can be classified as first time crooks. Sonny can also be classified with Sargent Moretti in the sense that they are both male roles demanding things from each other in order to get their way. Some obvious examples of grouping I could come up with were the actual hostages and the Brooklyn police department. The reason Sonny had hostages was because he was determined to get the money and he needed collateral. Sonny's determination could be looked at as crazy. I interpreted his determination as love for himself. He was trying to prove that he could get what he wants, which was for Leon to undergo the operation. In a way, it seems he wanted the operation more than Leon. An alternative to this viewpoint could be that Sonny loves Leon and will stop at nothing to get him what he wants. Love makes you do crazy things and Leon often refers to Sonny as crazy. If you think about it this way, it alters Sonny's character from a crazy man to a man crazy about another man.

Review title: Not worth watching more than a quarter of the movie since I only watched half
Review_body: This is the worst Al Pacino movie I've ever seen. It starts with little introduction, just some random shots of New York which have no relevance to the plot overall. Quickly, you find out that the characters are conducting a bank robbery, OK. Sure, the reason is revealed later, but at the beginning, you're looking for some kind of sense in the movie, and it's not to be found. Once the police come in, the movie seems to make even less sense, with the police being emasculated by Pacino's character, and surrounding crowd that supports a bank robber... it just doesn't make any sense, and it's quite hard to believe it was based on a true story. I guess Pacino's character was crazy at the time of this robbery, and that becomes quite plain, yet he's not really sympathetic or interesting, just crazy and bizarre. Even when he's nice and concerned with the hostages his character isn't sympathetic, because he doesn't come off as someone with a measure of sanity, and until the whole bit about his wife, you mind as well think there's no reason at all for his robbing the bank. Anyhow, I'll admit I only watched half of the movie, but that half was entirely monotonous, and a waste of an hour of my life.I don't know why people think this movie is so great. Serpico, Scarface and others are much better.

Review title: Uncanny resemblance between young Chris Sarandon & Mark Ruffalo
Review_body: I couldn't get over the resemblance between young Chris Sarandon, who played Leon, and Mark Ruffalo ("Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "You Can Count on Me"). When Leon first appeared in the movie, I was freaked. I thought for a moment it was actually Ruffalo in the role, but that didn't make any sense, since the movie was made in 1975, and Ruffalo was born just eight years earlier, in 1967. I never would have thought that Leon was played by the same guy who played Prince Humperdinck in "The Princess Bride."Anyone else notice this, or is it just me?---Terry from Seattle

Review title: One of the best and most realistic bank robbery movies ever made !
Review_body: The only reason I started watching this movie was "Al Pacino". I love his acting since the day I saw his masterpiece "Scarface". So when I started watching this movie I was thinking it would be like most of the other crime movies with some highly trained professionals and all, but I was wrong. This film showed a common man who tried to do what he is not trained for to help his friend with some money.This film is based on a true story.The movie also showed the behavior of society and people in conditions like bank robbery how they are influenced by television and media. Even though he just started at that time acting wise Al Pacino as always was superb next to scarface, godfather and scent of a woman. It showed his two faces of Al Pacino his good side and also the bad side. In short this is a great movie worth a watch. You won't be bored even for a moment. On top of that it will leave an impression on you about the good side of criminals and how situations change the mentality of a person.

Dog Day Afternoon is a brilliant mix of strong drama, riveting suspense and amusing humor. The direction of the film is astounding, since the film used less than 5 locations. Lumet's guidance of this film really gave the memorability to make it a shining classic of a tragic story. Dog Day Afternoon is really a film worth seeing.

Review title: Good acting with a useless robbery theme
Review_body: It may be a true story but this is one of the most boring and ridiculous robbery movie ever. However, Al Pacino has saved and justified movie a bit. How can it be so overrated!

While the acting is good, the story is more of a political statement than anything else.The cops are depicted as a ruthless unorganized gang of thugs unable to contain the situation and the hostages and public appear prejudiced to the view of bankrobbers as good guys from the start.This is emphasized by cowboy cops trying to engage the robber leaving the viewer somewhat bewildered as it takes quite a lot of courage to assail an unknown number of rifle-armed robbers with only a suit and a peashooter.Another point of confusion is that the group of thug-cops do not seem powerful or dominant in any way other than numerical presence; it takes a good 2 hours of soft negotation and media coverage where the robber is in complete control and where civilians and professionals are put in harms way without further thought.The robbery itself is justified by a weak reference to working-class struggle and a hint of then controversial sexuality issues.That may have satisfied the Oscar critics at the time, I'd hope the viewer have a more honest and realistic perspective of the morals of two heavily armed men pointing their guns at innocent civilians, whatever decade you live in.
